citation.article-title: Classification of some coryneform bacteria in a new genus Aureobacterium

p.s: Description of Aureobacterium liquefaciens nom. rev.; comb. nov.

On suitable solid media in air surface colonies are 1 to 3 mm dia., convex, circular with entire margin, opaque, glistening; a bright yellow pigment is produced. In young cultures, small, irregular rods occur; some cells are arranged at an angle to give V-formations. In older cultures rods become shorter but a marked rod-coccus cycle does not occur. Rods are Gram-positive, non-acid fast and non-motile; endospores are not formed. Optimum temperature ca. 30°C. Obligately aerobic.
Slow and weak, oxidative acid production, acid from D-glucose, galactose and a few other sugars.
Arginine, gelatin, aesculin and casein are hydrolysed.
Hippurate, Tween 20, 40 and 80 are not hydrolysed.
Cell wall peptidoglycan based upon D-ornithine, type B2β (i.e. [L-Hsr]-D-Glu-Gly-D-Orn; Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
Glycan moiety of peptidoglycan contains glycolyl and acetyl residues.
Rhamnose is the cell wall sugar.

Non-hydroxylated long chain fatty acids consist of predominantly anteiso and iso-methyl branched-chain acids; small amounts of straight-chain acids and traces of monounsaturated acids may also be present.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 and anteiso-C17.
Major menaquinones consist of MK-11 and MK-12.
Polar lipids comprise diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and diglycosyldiacylglycerol.
DNA base composition is 68.2 to 72.5 mol% G + C.
Habitat: usually found in milk, cheese, dairy products and on dairy equipment.
